I.  CHATTERTON IN MASQUERADE.</br>NARVA AND MORED;  AN AFRICAN ECLOGUE.</br>[From Chatterton's Miscellanies, p. 56.]

Recyte the loves of Narva and Mored,</br>The preeste of Chalmas trypell ydolle sayde,</br>Hie fro the grounde the youthful heretogs (a) sprunge,</br>Loude on the concave shelle the launces runge:</br>In al the mysterke (b) maizes of the daunce</br>The youths of Bannies brennynge (c) sandes advaunce;</br>Whiles the mole (d) vyrgin brokkyng (e) lookes behinde,</br>And rydes uponne the penyons of the winde;</br>Astighes (f) the mountaines borne (g), and measures rounde</br>The steepie clifftes of Chalmas hallie (h) grounde.
a.  Warriors.  b. mystick.  c. burning.  d. used by Chatterton for "soft" or "tender."  e. panting.  f. ascends.  g.  brow, or summit.  h. holy.
II.  CHATTERTON UNMASKED.</br>ECLOGUE THE FIRST.</br>[From Rowley's Poems, quarto, p. 391.]

When England smoking from her deadly wound,</br>From her gall'd neck did twitch the chain away,</br>Seeing her lawfull sons fall all around,</br>(Mighty they fell, 'twas Honour led the fray,)</br>Then in a dale, by eve's dark surcoat gray,</br>Two lonely shepherds did abruptly fly,</br>(The rustling leaf does their white hearts affray,)</br>And with the owlet trembled and did cry:</br>First Robert Neatherd his sore bosom struck,</br>Then fell upon the ground, and thus he spoke.</br>
